article.title: The Difference between Physics and Biology: The Key Role of Biomolecules

choices: The hierarchy of life and the flow of genetic information from DNA to proteins.
The role of biomolecules in generating action potentials in neurons.
The contextual control of lower-level processes by higher-level contexts in biological systems.
The process of adaptive selection shaping the development of eyes.
The role of energy minimization in protein folding.
The structure and function of voltage-gated ion channels.
The top-down regulation of a metabolic pathway module by higher-order circuits.
The process of deductive causation in human decision-making.
The structure of the citric acid cycle and its role in cellular energy production.
The process of gene expression and its regulation by transcription factors.
The three-dimensional structure of potassium ion channels and their role in ion flow.
The interplay between single voltage-channel receptors and receptors responding to global synaptic inputs.
The process of Darwinian selection shaping the development of complex life forms.
The structure of cell interactions, highlighting the role of enzymes, folding, and membrane transport.
The neural architecture of a simple perceptual inference model, illustrating Bayesian brain processes.
The supply chain for adenosine triphosphate (ATP) production, which powers neuronal activity.
The process of chemotaxis in bacteria, demonstrating branching logic.
The reading of the genetic code, translating codons into amino acids.
The basic selection process, filtering an input ensemble to produce an ordered output.
The adaptive Bayesian brain, minimizing prediction errors based on sensory input.
The molecular basis of branching logic, showing how biomolecules function as logic gates.
The hierarchy of biological emergence, illustrating how proteins link physics and biological causation.
A model of the neural architecture involved in simple perceptual inference, highlighting Bayesian processes.
The role of neuroenergetics in powering brain processes, including deductive thought.
The interplay between top-down and bottom-up processes in brain function.
The process of adaptation in biological systems, occurring at multiple levels and timescales.
The supply chain for ATP production, providing energy for neuronal activity.
The process of deductive causation, enabling intelligent organisms to transcend physical limitations.

multiple_choice_question.text: What function do the protein gradients shown in Figure 9 serve?
choices: To facilitate the propagation of action potentials in neuronal axons.
To regulate the transcription of genes through the lock-and-key mechanism.
To enable aberration-free vision in squid eyes.
To maintain the intracellular milieu required for supermolecular chemistry processes.
The deterministic evolution of a physical system according to physical laws.
The probabilistic outcomes of states in statistical physics.
The branching logic that governs biological dynamics, shaped by context and function.
The equation of motion for a particle in electromagnetic and gravitational fields.

multiple_choice_question.text: What type of biological process does Formula (7) describe?
choices: The adaptive selection of proteins based on their physiological roles.
The reading of the genetic code, translating codons into amino acids.
The functioning of feedback control circuits that maintain homeostasis.
The process of deductive causation, enabling logical decision-making.

multiple_choice_question.text: What cyclical process does Formula (19) summarize?
choices: The operation of a metabolic pathway module converting food to energy.
The propagation of action potentials in neuronal axons.
The adaptive selection process leading to the evolution of traits.
The Bayesian brain\'s prediction of likely components of the prediction error.
The mathematical relationship between energy and mass according to special relativity.
The basic branching logic underlying the deletion of elements not fulfilling a specific selection criterion.
The equation describing the total membrane current in the Hodgkin-Huxley model.
The function used by the brain to determine the most likely value given by Bayes\' rule.
The probabilistic logical argument based on statistical evidence.
The deductive choice of best actions based on logical predictions of outcomes.
The process of adaptation through the variation and elimination of traits.
The role of biomolecules in performing branching logical operations.
